<p>To find the best power bank out there, I tested around 50 portable chargers and batteries from big brands — Anker, Belkin, UGreen, Mophie — as well as some smaller players like Lion Energy, Nimble and Satechi. I used them to recharge a number of devices including iPhones, Galaxy phones, an iPad, a MacBook and even my ereaders and PlayStation controller. If you just want a brick that can charge anything, go for <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:Amazon;elmt:;cpos:1;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=66ea567a-c987-4c2e-a2ff-02904efde6ea&amp;itemId=amazon_B0DCBB2YTR&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=Amazon&amp;linkText=Anker%E2%80%99s+25kmAh+Laptop+Power+bank&amp;custData=eyJzb3VyY2VOYW1lIjoiV2ViLURlc2t0b3AtVmVyaXpvbiIsImxhbmRpbmdVcmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy5hbWF6b24uY29tL2RwL0IwRENCQjJZVFI_dGFnPWdkZ3QwYy0yMCIsImNvbnRlbnRVdWlkIjoiMTE0OWQxOGEtMzY2ZC00MWU3LTljZmEtN2NlNGQwZmQ2ODM1Iiwib3JpZ2luYWxVcmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy5hbWF6b24uY29tL2RwL0IwRENCQjJZVFIiLCJkeW5hbWljQ2VudHJhbFRyYWNraW5nSWQiOnRydWUsInNpdGVJZCI6InVzLWVuZ2FkZ2V0IiwicGFnZUlkIjoiMXAtYXV0b2xpbmsiLCJmZWF0dXJlSWQiOiJ0ZXh0LWxpbmsifQ&amp;signature=AQAAAe19jAxhB8OOgSsiW37JLPwsKIfvES9czU79gDRAYg_b&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2Fdp%2FB0DCBB2YTR" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0DCBB2YTR?th=1">Anker’s 25kmAh Laptop Power bank</a>. It has two built-in USB-C cables, a massive capacity and super fast charging speeds. But if that’s not quite what you’re looking for, you can check out ten more of the best power banks below.<br><br><strong>Editor’s note</strong>: Anker <ins>recently issued two recalls</ins>, one for its <a data-i13n="cpos:2;pos:1" href="https://www.engadget.com/mobile/anker-recalls-over-a-million-power-banks-due-to-fire-and-burn-hazards-110017437.html"><ins>PowerCore 10000 power bank</ins></a> (model A1263) and another for <a data-i13n="cpos:3;pos:1" href="https://www.engadget.com/mobile/anker-issues-another-recall-for-multiple-power-banks-that-pose-fire-safety-risk-160015082.html"><ins>multiple power banks</ins></a> (model numbers A1647, A1652, A1257, A1681 and A1689). All recalls are due to a potential fire risk in the lithium-ion cells. If you have one of these batteries, visit <a data-i13n="elm:context_link;elmt:doNotAffiliate;cpos:4;pos:1" class="no-affiliate-link" href="https://www.anker.com/a1263-recall"><ins>Anker’s recall page for the next steps</ins></a>. None of the batteries we currently recommend are part of the recall, and we haven’t recommended these specific models in previous iterations of this guide.</p>

<h2 id="jump-link-what-to-look-for-in-a-portable-battery-pack">What to look for in a portable battery pack</h2> 
<h3 id="jump-link-battery-type"><strong>Battery type</strong></h3> 
<p>Nearly every rechargeable power bank you can buy (and most portable devices) contain a lithium-ion battery. These beat other current battery types in terms of size-to-charge capacity, and have even <a data-i13n="cpos:10;pos:1" href="https://www.energy.gov/eere/vehicles/articles/fotw-1234-april-18-2022-volumetric-energy-density-lithium-ion-batteries">increased</a> in energy density by eight fold in the past 14 years. They also don’t <a data-i13n="cpos:11;pos:1" href="https://www.cei.washington.edu/education/science-of-solar/battery-technology/">suffer</a> from a memory effect (where a battery's lifespan deteriorates due to partial charges).</p> <span id="end-legacy-contents"></span>
<h3 id="jump-link-flying-with-portable-batteries"><strong>Flying with portable batteries</strong></h3> 
<p>You may have heard about lithium ion batteries overheating and catching fire — a recent Hong Kong flight was grounded after <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:The Independent;elmt:;cpos:12;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=9b10ec1f-8e62-4410-8957-c54f7db63bfc&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=The+Independent&amp;linkText=just+such+a+thing+happened&amp;&amp;signature=AQAAAeU3AdLXhHs4rETBPmT2Fa8cfZB6yJ3Rqk5g0VxDNdcc&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.independent.co.uk%2Ftravel%2Fnews-and-advice%2Fhong-kong-airlines-flight-fire-power-bank-b2719164.html" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/news-and-advice/hong-kong-airlines-flight-fire-power-bank-b2719164.html">just such a thing happened</a> in an overhead bin. Current restrictions implemented by the <a data-i13n="cpos:13;pos:1" href="https://www.tsa.gov/travel/security-screening/whatcanibring/items/lithium-batteries-100-watt-hours-or-less-device">TSA</a> still allow external batteries rated at 100Wh or less (which all of our recommendations are) to fly with you, but only in your carry-on luggage — they can’t be checked.</p> 
<p>Recently, Southwest Airlines was the <a data-i13n="cpos:14;pos:1" href="https://www.npr.org/2025/05/21/nx-s1-5406294/southwest-airlines-will-require-passengers-to-keep-chargers-visible-due-to-fire-risk">first in the industry</a> to take that rule one step further. Now, flyers on that airline must keep power banks in clear view when using them to recharge a device. If the portable charger isn’t actively in use, however, it can stay in your carry-on bag in the overhead bin.</p> 
<h3 id="jump-link-capacity"><strong>Capacity</strong></h3> 
<p>Power bank manufacturers almost always list a battery’s capacity in milliamp hours, or mAh. Smaller batteries with a 5,000mAh capacity make good phone chargers and can fill a smartphone to between 50 and 75 percent. Larger batteries that can recharge laptops and tablets, or give phones multiple charges, can exceed 25,000mAh and we have a <a data-i13n="cpos:15;pos:1" href="https://www.engadget.com/best-laptop-power-bank-120040388.html">separate guide</a> that covers that entire category.&nbsp;</p> 
<p>Unsurprisingly, the prices on most batteries goes up as mAh capacity increases, and since batteries are physical storage units, size and weight go up with capacity as well. If you want more power, be prepared to spend more and carry around a heavier brick.</p> 
<p>You might think that a 10,000mAh power bank could charge a 5,000mAh phone to 100 percent twice, but that’s not the case. In addition to simple energy loss through heat dissipation, factors like voltage conversion also bring down the amount of juice that makes it into your phone. Most manufacturers list how many charges a battery can give a certain smartphone. In our tests, 10,000mAh of battery pack capacity translated to roughly 5,800mAh of device charge. 20,000mAh chargers delivered around 11,250mAh to a device, and 25,000mAh banks translated to about 16,200mAh of charge. That’s an average efficiency rate of around 60 percent.</p> 
<p><strong>Wireless</strong></p> 
<p>More manufacturers are making power banks with wireless charging. Not hassling with cables is nice, but it’s important to note that wireless charging is <a data-i13n="cpos:16;pos:1" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vhKVuT8-H1g">less efficient</a> than plugging in your phone. Outside of MagSafe options, wireless portable chargers historically didn’t make the cut for our top picks for this guide for that reason. The <a data-i13n="cpos:17;pos:1" href="https://www.chargewithqi.com/qi2/">Qi2</a> wireless charging standard arrived in 2023 and improves performance for wireless charging, including for portable banks. Currently, iPhones are the only handsets that support the new tech, but as it’s an open standard, expect Google, Samsung and others to adopt it for future phones. In my testing, I’ve noticed an uptick in the performance of non-Qi2-enabled batteries as well, so you'll now see wireless options on this list.</p> 
<p><strong>Ports</strong></p> 
<p>Since Apple ditched the Lightning cable and <a data-i13n="cpos:18;pos:1" href="https://www.engadget.com/apples-switch-to-usb-c-on-the-iphone-15-brings-more-cable-confusion-140030611.html">adopted</a> USB-C, we’re getting closer to a standard for charging connections — and all of our picks have at least one such port. But plenty of other devices use older interfaces, like USB-A and microUSB ports, plus Lightning for older iPhones. You can find cables with just about any combination of those connections, so when you’re picking out a battery, just check that one end of your preferred cord will fit.</p> 
<p>Most battery packs have more than one charging port, which gives you different charging options. You’ll typically see at least one port labeled “in/out,” which means you can use it to both charge the bank and charge your gadget. While USB-A output ports can power up cell phones and other small devices, they can’t charge larger devices. Plus, they aren’t as fast as USB-C ports overall. That’s something to keep in mind when you’re deciding which ports and charging cables to use to connect your phone to the pack.</p> 
<p>There’s even more variation among USB-C ports themselves, with different ports on the same device supporting different power transfer rates. What that means in practical terms is an iPhone will charge just fine plugged into a power bank’s 18W port. But to properly charge, say, a MacBook or similar laptop, it’ll need the extra juice supplied by a 100W port (which larger power banks can offer). Power banks with more than one port can also charge multiple devices at the same time, but speeds and the overall charge delivered will be lower.</p> 
<p>You’ll also want to consider your charging cable. For anything larger than a smartphone (and to access fast-charging capabilities) you’ll want to use USB-C ports and cables. But not all cables are created equal, even when they have the same USB-C plugs on the end. If you want power delivery from a 100W USB-C power bank port, you’ll need a 100W-rated USB-C cable. Luckily, power banks capable of delivering 100W tend to include a compatible cable. For any devices that don’t, we’ve tried and liked <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:Amazon;elmt:;cpos:19;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=66ea567a-c987-4c2e-a2ff-02904efde6ea&amp;itemId=amazon_B08PVQC5C6&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=Amazon&amp;linkText=Anker%E2%80%99s+100W+USB-C+cable&amp;custData=eyJzb3VyY2VOYW1lIjoiV2ViLURlc2t0b3AtVmVyaXpvbiIsImxhbmRpbmdVcmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy5hbWF6b24uY29tL2dwL3Byb2R1Y3QvQjA4UFZRQzVDNi8_&amp;signature=AQAAAUn47ojB1hGao4ceT2jTBcFhHUIHTDSSP9Nm2Z3KbLu4&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2Fgp%2Fproduct%2FB08PVQC5C6%2F" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=66ea567a-c987-4c2e-a2ff-02904efde6ea&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=Amazon&amp;&amp;signature=AQAAAR_xsREa_And-v6ZXl_ejxtt2D4oWXYQ-2zL5SSYmK0M&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2Fgp%2Fproduct%2FB08PVQC5C6%2F%3Fth%3D1">Anker’s 100W USB-C cable</a>. For smaller devices, we used this <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:nimble;elmt:;cpos:20;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=88872e72-f0df-4301-b936-bf22f074034c&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=nimble&amp;linkText=60W+cable+from+Nimble&amp;&amp;signature=AQAAAUJi4qT3HikT5KOmjSH42mkgp_ev1bDUI295pciAlZLf&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.gonimble.com%2Fcollections%2Fusb-c-cables%2Fproducts%2Fusb-c-cable-powerknit" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;custData=eyJzb3VyY2VOYW1lIjoiV2ViLURlc2t0b3AtVmVyaXpvbiIsImxhbmRpbmdVcmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy5nb25pbWJsZS5jb20vY29sbGVjdGlvbnMvdXNiLWMtY2FibGVzL3Byb2R1Y3RzL3VzYi1jLWNhYmxlLXBvd2Vya25pdCIsImNvbnRlbnRVdWlkIjoiMTE0OWQxOGEtMzY2ZC00MWU3LTljZmEtN2NlNGQwZmQ2ODM1In0&amp;signature=AQAAAWJmFK5yLOrU_OxXHu5r_FfdjuwPrTE0Drz9ZoHY5j4C&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.gonimble.com%2Fcollections%2Fusb-c-cables%2Fproducts%2Fusb-c-cable-powerknit">60W cable from Nimble</a> and we don’t recommend bothering with cables under 60W. For around $20, higher-capacity charging cables will make sure you’re not wasting time with connections that limit your potential power transfer.</p> 
<h3 id="jump-link-design"><strong>Design</strong></h3> 
<p>For the most part, these rechargeable batteries have a squared-off, brick-like design, though many nod towards aesthetics with attractive finishes and detailing. While that doesn’t affect how they perform, it’s a consideration for something you’ll interact with regularly. Some portable power stations include extra features like MagSafe compatibility, a built-in wall plug or even a kickstand. Nearly all have some sort of indicator to let you know how much available charge your power bank has left, usually expressed with lighted pips near the power button. Some of the newer banks take that a step further with an LED display indicating remaining battery percentage.</p> 
<h2 id="jump-link-how-we-test-best-power-banks">How we test best power banks</h2> 
<p>Before I even put my hands on a battery pack, I did extensive research. I considered brands Engadget reviewers and staff have tried over the years and checked out customer ratings on retail sites like Amazon and Best Buy. Then, I acquire the most promising candidates and test them in my home office.</p>

<p>We're continuously updating this guide as companies release new products and we test them. We remove some products as we find picks that are more worthy of the best portable charger designation. We also add updated specs and prices where necessary.&nbsp;</p> 
<p>For testing, I used each battery with some combination of an iPhone 15, an iPhone 14 Plus, an iPhone 11, a Samsung Galaxy S22 Ultra, a Galaxy S23 Ultra, a 5th-gen iPad Air and an M1 Pro 16-inch MacBook Pro. I charged one phone battery at a time, even though some packs are capable of multiple-device charging. I charged the phones and tablets from between zero and five percent until they were 100 percent full (or until the power bank was dead), and didn’t use the phones or tablets while they charged other than to power them on and enter the unlock code. In the case of the MacBook, I used it while it was charging (it’s my work computer).</p> 
<p>I used the charging cable included with each power bank to charge the Galaxy S22 Ultra, MacBook Pro and the iPad Air. For the iPhones, I used the USB-C to Lighting cable that Apple provides. In the case of the lower-capacity power banks that didn’t include a cord or included one with USB-C to USB-A connectors, I used this <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:nimble;elmt:;cpos:59;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=88872e72-f0df-4301-b936-bf22f074034c&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=nimble&amp;linkText=60W-rated+USB-C+to+USB-C+cable&amp;&amp;signature=AQAAAUJi4qT3HikT5KOmjSH42mkgp_ev1bDUI295pciAlZLf&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.gonimble.com%2Fcollections%2Fusb-c-cables%2Fproducts%2Fusb-c-cable-powerknit" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://www.gonimble.com/collections/usb-c-cables/products/usb-c-cable-powerknit">60W-rated USB-C to USB-C cable</a>.</p> 
<p>For reference, here are the battery capacities of each device we used for testing:</p> 
<ul> 
 <li><p>iPhone 11: 3,110 mAh</p></li> 
 <li><p>iPhone 14 Plus: 4,325 mAh</p></li> 
 <li><p><a data-i13n="cpos:60;pos:1" href="https://www.macrumors.com/2023/09/15/iphone-15-battery-capacities-revealed/">iPhone 15</a>: 3,349 mAh</p></li> 
 <li><p><a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:Samsung Electronics;elmt:;cpos:61;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=f85e63cd-e13c-4f9d-991c-9fbaadede3ac&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=Samsung+Electronics&amp;linkText=Galaxy+S22+Ultra&amp;&amp;signature=AQAAAfWlGFR0kTXzYAl26i8fj1md2hczvBLquyCyXGmPUtMf&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.samsung.com%2Flevant%2Fsmartphones%2Fgalaxy-s22-ultra%2Fspecs%2F" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://www.samsung.com/levant/smartphones/galaxy-s22-ultra/specs/">Galaxy S22 Ultra</a>: 4,855mAh</p></li> 
 <li><p><a data-i13n="cpos:62;pos:1" href="https://support.apple.com/kb/SP866?locale=en_US">iPad Air</a>: 7,729mAh</p></li> 
 <li><p>16-inch M1 Pro MacBook Pro: 27,027mAh</p></li>

<p>I noted the times for each charge and the number of charges each bank provided. I also paid attention to things like ease of use and overall design.</p> 
<h2 id="jump-link-other-power-banks-we-tested">Other power banks we tested</h2> 
<h3 id="jump-link-anker-prime-20000-mah-power-bank"><strong>Anker Prime 20,000 mAh power bank</strong></h3> 
<p>Anker’s <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:Amazon;elmt:;cpos:63;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=66ea567a-c987-4c2e-a2ff-02904efde6ea&amp;itemId=amazon_B0BYNZXFM2&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=Amazon&amp;linkText=Prime+bank&amp;custData=eyJzb3VyY2VOYW1lIjoiV2ViLURlc2t0b3AtVmVyaXpvbiIsImxhbmRpbmdVcmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy5hbWF6b24uY29tL0Fua2VyLVBvcnRhYmxlLUNoYXJnZXItRGlnaXRhbC1Db21wYXRpYmxlL2RwL0IwQllOWlhGTTI_&amp;signature=AQAAAfnlL8x-0aZr0en3LMV0pX7aYwvli0rKoMocUtUk_WM6&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FAnker-Portable-Charger-Digital-Compatible%2Fdp%2FB0BYNZXFM2" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://www.amazon.com/Anker-Portable-Charger-Digital-Compatible/dp/B0BYNZXFM2">Prime bank</a> was our previous pick for the best premium power bank, but I thought it worked best with the expensive (yet very convenient) base. Considering it also doesn’t have any built-in cables, we decided to bump the Prime battery from its position and replace it with the <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:Anker;elmt:;cpos:64;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=aac3354f-048f-410b-ae8a-eb1da43ee6cf&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=Anker&amp;linkText=Anker+Retractable+Cable+Laptop+Bank&amp;&amp;signature=AQAAAZWCjY36C7uW7o7BVSmhyfIOvUJ0YP7y2DmG4yCmv_iw&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.anker.com%2Fproducts%2Fa1695-anker-power-bank-25000mah-165w%3Fvariant%3D44320657997974" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://www.anker.com/products/a1695-anker-power-bank-25000mah-165w?variant=44320657997974">Anker Retractable Cable Laptop Bank</a>. There’s still plenty to like about the Prime battery: it’s solid, attractive and tells you just how much charge it has left with its onboard display. When you add the optional base, you not only get a convenient drop-and-go way to recharge, it also acts as a charging hub with three additional USB ports.</p> 
<h3 id="jump-link-ecoflow-rapid-magnetic-power-bank"><strong>EcoFlow Rapid magnetic power bank</strong></h3> 
<p>I was curious to try out the first power bank from EcoFlow, a company that primarily makes larger power stations and whole-home <a data-i13n="cpos:65;pos:1" href="https://www.engadget.com/the-ecoflow-delta-pro-ultra-is-a-home-battery-that-can-harvest-power-from-42-solar-panels-190032452.html?guccounter=1&amp;guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&amp;guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAAEufKxgWteWNCu3R9pldJLME6Ik2e013731N1jiT3NntZJaG_DoowjYuTcFJADyOVagbkTD2n414zlqmwDrHUBEe7rWdtkotScjOaree7X0ti2EPpyS7W5tCyXVuC-ssLrpsXn2HlciPxCLjeIdZBCr5zYYH3aI8uj_PvkOJXEi">backup batteries</a>. The first offering in the brand’s Rapid series is a <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:EcoFlow;elmt:;cpos:66;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=3d83331c-7ecd-4753-90c4-5dd59cd82015&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=EcoFlow&amp;linkText=Qi2-enabled+magnetic+charger+with+a+5%2C000mAh+capacity&amp;&amp;signature=AQAAATtzHbsyENsfO5CTiY33ulaTPHDq97GzCTTcvFknLenQ&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fus.ecoflow.com%2Fproducts%2Frapid-magnetic-power-bank-5000mah%3Fvariant%3D41843266584649" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://us.ecoflow.com/products/rapid-magnetic-power-bank-5000mah?variant=41843266584649">Qi2-enabled magnetic charger with a 5,000mAh capacity</a>. It looks quite nice with shiny silver accents and soft-touch grey plastic on the MagSafe-compatible front. There’s a little pull-out leg that sturdily displays your phone as it charges and the attached USB-C cable lets you refill devices directly, then tucks out of the way when it’s not in use. But it didn’t outperform our top pick in the MagSafe category, in terms of both charging speeds and the amount of charge delivered.</p> 
<h3 id="jump-link-baseus-blade-2">Baseus Blade 2</h3> 
<p>The <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:Amazon;elmt:;cpos:67;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=66ea567a-c987-4c2e-a2ff-02904efde6ea&amp;itemId=amazon_B0CQT9XLH3&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=Amazon&amp;linkText=Blade+2+from+Baseus&amp;custData=eyJzb3VyY2VOYW1lIjoiV2ViLURlc2t0b3AtVmVyaXpvbiIsImxhbmRpbmdVcmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy5hbWF6b24uY29tL0Jhc2V1cy1DaGFyZ2luZy1Db250cm9sLTEyMDAwbUFoLVBvcnRhYmxlL2RwL0IwQ1FUOVhMSDM_&amp;signature=AQAAAefAdFrJ13b_Yk2OjsmL9QYQqiLblQeHAATuv-lhTpki&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FBaseus-Charging-Control-12000mAh-Portable%2Fdp%2FB0CQT9XLH3" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://www.amazon.com/Baseus-Charging-Control-12000mAh-Portable/dp/B0CQT9XLH3">Blade 2 from Baseus</a> has a unique, flat shape that’s just a little wider than an ereader — which may make it easier to slip into a low profile laptop bag. It charged a Samsung Galaxy S23 Ultra considerably faster than any other battery bank we tried, getting it from four percent to full in just over an hour. It then filled the phone back to 62 percent from dead on a second charge in about a half an hour. But $100 is a lot for a standard power bank that holds fewer than two full charges. But if you can find the Blade 2 on sale, snap it up.</p> 
<h3 id="jump-link-anker-maggo-66k">Anker MagGo (6.6K)</h3> 
<p>Anker’s <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:Amazon;elmt:;cpos:68;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=66ea567a-c987-4c2e-a2ff-02904efde6ea&amp;itemId=amazon_B0C9DNYKMJ&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=Amazon&amp;linkText=6.6k+MagGo&amp;&amp;signature=AQAAASG50h9JT3P5uLgfeQ-cymZsu9G5mXfOOAXYbkG6a5kn&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FAnker-Certified-Ultra-Fast-MagSafe-Compatible-Adjustable%2Fdp%2FB0C9DNYKMJ%2F" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://www.amazon.com/Anker-Certified-Ultra-Fast-MagSafe-Compatible-Adjustable/dp/B0C9DNYKMJ/">6.6k MagGo</a> is pretty similar to our top pick for a MagSafe-compatible battery pack. It supports the Qi2 charging standard and props up your iPhone so you can use it or enable StandBy mode while powering up. This one even lets you set the viewing angle from 30 to 65 degrees. It was speedy in getting an iPhone 15 up to 50 percent in about 40 minutes. But for the added bulk, it doesn’t have as much capacity as the 10K MagGo, holding just enough juice for a single full charge plus about 5 percent. But it is $20 cheaper, which may be key for some.</p> 
<h3 id="jump-link-mophie-snap-powerstation-mini">Mophie Snap+ Powerstation Mini</h3> 
<p>The <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:Zagg;elmt:;cpos:69;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=6391fb09-49b1-4860-b92a-12edb53cb14e&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=Zagg&amp;linkText=Mophie+snap%2B+Powerstation+Mini&amp;&amp;signature=AQAAAS3hVei9Sy_Z3Hf-IZAagq2o0A3Eq_abT3tAqbo-oP4j&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.zagg.com%2Fsnap-powerstation-mini-with-stand%2F" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://www.zagg.com/snap-powerstation-mini-with-stand/">Mophie snap+ Powerstation Mini</a> is terribly well-built. It feels premium with a rubberized contact point for the MagSafe charging pad and a stand that runs the entire width of the bank itself, making it extra sturdy. It’s compact, too, but only carries a 5,000mAh capacity, which gets you a partial charge on most newer or larger phones. Our current <a data-i13n="elm:affiliate_link;sellerN:Amazon;elmt:;cpos:70;pos:1" href="https://shopping.yahoo.com/rdlw?merchantId=66ea567a-c987-4c2e-a2ff-02904efde6ea&amp;itemId=amazon_B0CFDQ9QH5&amp;siteId=us-engadget&amp;pageId=1p-autolink&amp;contentUuid=1149d18a-366d-41e7-9cfa-7ce4d0fd6835&amp;featureId=text-link&amp;merchantName=Amazon&amp;linkText=MagSafe%2FiPhone+pick&amp;custData=eyJzb3VyY2VOYW1lIjoiV2ViLURlc2t0b3AtVmVyaXpvbiIsImxhbmRpbmdVcmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy5hbWF6b24uY29tL2RwL0IwQ0ZEUTlRSDU_dGFnPWdkZ3QwYy0yMCIsImNvbnRlbnRVdWlkIjoiMTE0OWQxOGEtMzY2ZC00MWU3LTljZmEtN2NlNGQwZmQ2ODM1Iiwib3JpZ2luYWxVcmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy5hbWF6b24uY29tL2RwL0IwQ0ZEUTlRSDUiLCJkeW5hbWljQ2VudHJhbFRyYWNraW5nSWQiOnRydWUsInNpdGVJZCI6InVzLWVuZ2FkZ2V0IiwicGFnZUlkIjoiMXAtYXV0b2xpbmsiLCJmZWF0dXJlSWQiOiJ0ZXh0LWxpbmsifQ&amp;signature=AQAAAQDsV79b60JDo8Zxxo8g3TdO1fqT9iIGRcsuOV_YT5bv&amp;gcReferrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2Fdp%2FB0CFDQ9QH5" class="rapid-with-clickid" data-original-link="https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0CFDQ9QH5">MagSafe/iPhone pick</a> has double the capacity, a stand and a digital display — for just $20 more than the Powerstation Mini.</p> 
<h2 id="jump-link-power-bank-faqs">Power bank FAQs</h2> 
<h3 id="jump-link-whats-the-difference-between-a-portable-power-bank-and-a-portable-charger"><strong>What's the difference between a portable power bank and a portable charger?</strong></h3> 
<p>A slew of terms are used to describe power banks, including portable batteries, portable chargers, external battery packs and even, somewhat confusingly, USB chargers, which is what wall chargers are often called. They all mean the same thing: a lithium ion battery that stores a charge so you can refill a smartphone, tablet, earbuds, console controller, ereader, laptop, or just about any other device with its own built-in, rechargeable battery.&nbsp;</p> 
<p>There’s little difference between the terms, so the specs you’ll want to pay attention to are capacity (expressed in mAh), size and weight so you can find the right balance between recharging what you need and portability.</p> 
<p>Power stations, on the other hand, are distinct. These are bigger units (often around the size of a car battery) that can be used to charge multiple devices multiple times, but notably, they can’t be taken on airplanes.</p> 
<h3 id="jump-link-does-fast-charging-actually-ruin-your-battery"><strong>Does fast charging actually ruin your battery?</strong></h3> 
<p>Not exactly. The real enemy of a battery’s longevity is heat. The faster you charge a battery, the more heat is generated. Modern phones have features that keep the battery cool while charging, like physical heat shields and heat sinks, as well as software features that slow down processes that generate too much heat. Phone manufacturers are keen to promote a phone’s fast-charging abilities, so they had to figure out ways to make faster charging work.</p> 
<p>While there aren’t long-term studies on what fast charging does to a phone, a <a data-i13n="cpos:71;pos:1" href="https://avt.inl.gov/sites/default/files/pdf/vehiclebatteries/FastChargeEffects.pdf">study on EV batteries</a> (which use the same general concept of charged lithium ions flowing from one side of the battery to the other, absorbing or releasing a usable charge) showed a very slight decrease in capacity over time with only fast charging — though what actually made a larger difference was how hot the battery itself was, due to ambient temperatures, when it was charged.</p> 
<p>In short, fast charging could be <em>slightly</em> harder on your battery than normal charging. But the safeguards most smartphones have make that difference fairly negligible. To really ensure you’re taking the best care of your battery, limiting heat exposure overall is one of the best things you can do.</p> 
<h3 id="jump-link-can-you-use-a-power-bank-for-all-your-devices"><strong>Can you use a power bank for all your devices?</strong></h3> 
<p>That depends on the size of the bank and the size of your device’s battery. A small 5,000mAh battery isn’t strong enough to charge laptops, but a portable charger with a 20,000mAh capacity will give your computer a partial refill. You also have to consider port compatibility. If your device has a USB port, you’ll be able to easily find a cable to connect it to a battery. If your device has a more unique port, such as a DC port, you won’t be able to use a battery. Devices with an AC cable and plug can be charged, and sometimes powered (such as in the case of a printer or speaker), by larger <a data-i13n="cpos:72;pos:1" href="https://www.engadget.com/computing/accessories/best-laptop-power-bank-120040388.html">laptop batteries</a> with AC ports.</p>This article originally appeared on Engadget at https://www.engadget.com/computing/accessories/best-power-bank-143048526.html?src=rss
